citeinfo.title: Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025 - MINERAL INDUSTRY TRENDS AND SALIENT STATISTICS Data Release

descript.abstract: This data release contains the U.S. salient statistics and world production data extracted from the tables and figures of the USGS Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025 that give an overview of the U.S. mineral industry in 2024.
descript.purpose: Published on an annual basis, the USGS Mineral Commodity Summaries report is the earliest Government publication to furnish estimates covering nonfuel mineral industry data. Data sheets contain information on the domestic industry structure, Government programs, tariffs, and 5-year salient statistics for over 90 individual minerals and materials.
descript.supplinf: Where possible, data are those finalized for publication in the 2023 U.S. Geological Survey Minerals Yearbook Volume I - Metals and Minerals. For 2024, USGS National Minerals Information Center provided estimates based on available data from USGS surveys of the industry, other industry sources, and mineral commodity specialist research.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

citeinfo.title: USGS National Minerals Information Center Web Page
citeinfo.othercit: Provides information and links to all available USGS National Minerals Information Center publications by commodity and by geographic area.

attracc.attraccr: Where possible, data for all years except 2024 have been finalized for publication in the U.S. Geological Survey Minerals Yearbook Volume I - Metals and Minerals; otherwise the data are noted as estimated.

dataqual.logic: Data were checked to ensure that they match those published in the Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025. Data were peer reviewed by Mineral Commodity Specialists and approved by supervisors in compliance with USGS fundamental science practices.
dataqual.complete: This data release contains tabular data found in the associated publication Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025 (MCS 2025); additional detailed information is available in the full text version of MCS 2025.

citeinfo.title: USGS Minerals Yearbook Volume I - Metals and Minerals

srcinfo.srccontr: Source of salient statistics for 2020 through 2023 and basis for estimates for 2024. The data in the Minerals Yearbook are based on USGS surveys sent to companies involved in the industry for each mineral commodity.
trade statistics for 2018 through 2021 and basis of trade statistics estimates for 2023
Data on employment and wages in mineral-related industries

citeinfo.title: Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization - G.17

srcinfo.srccontr: Capacity utilization and industrial production indexes related to the mining and minderal processing industries.
U.S. gross domestic product and contributions by mineral-related industries.

procstep.procdesc: Salient statistics for each mineral commodity were compiled from published 2023 U.S. Geological Survey Minerals Yearbook Volume I - Metals and Minerals chapters or from finalized tables of those to be published. Data for 2024 were estimated based on available 2023 data and industry trends. Economic data were compiled from various other Federal agencies that are relevant to the U.S. mineral mining and processing industries in relation to the total U.S economy. These data were published in tables and figures accompanying the text of the Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025 overview section. Data from the most current available 2024 economic releases were used as a basis for estimates for the year 2024 made by U.S Geological Survey mineral industry specialists.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.Note: Not all mineral commodities covered in this publication are listed here. Those not shown include mineral commodities for which the United States was a net exporter (abrasives, metallic; beryllium; boron; cadmium; clays; diatomite; gold; helium; iron and steel scrap; iron ore; kyanite; molybdenum; rare earths, mineral concentrates; sand and gravel, industrial; soda ash; titanium dioxide pigment; wollastonite; zeolites; and zinc, ores and concentrates) or less than 20% net import reliant (gypsum; iron and steel; iron and steel slag; lime; nitrogen, fixedâ€”ammonia; phosphate rock; pumice and pumicite; sand and gravel, construction; stone, crushed; sulfur; and talc and pyrophyllite). For some mineral commodities (hafnium; mercury; quartz, high-purity and industrial cultured crystal; thallium; and thorium), available information was inadequate to calculate the exact percentage of import reliance.

attr.attrdef: Publication in which the data were published

The order in which the commodity appears int the table as published, sorted by net import reliance percent and then alphabetically. Note that some commodities have a greater than or less than sign next to the percent, in which case an exact rank determination was not possible.
Commodity for which net import reliance is being determined
Net import reliance as a percentage of apparent consumption, estimated

attrdomv.udom: Values are generally in a numeric range of percentages from 20 to 100 but in some cases only a minimum percentage can be determined. the categories in these cases are as follows: <25, meaning less than 25 percent >25, meaning more than 25 percent >50, meaning more than 50 percent >75, meaning more than 75 percent >95, meaning more than 95 percent.

attr.attrdef: The leading countries, up to 4, from which the commodity is imported, as calculated by average imports from 2020 to 2023.

Cesium, erbium, gadolinium, hafnium, holmium, lutetium, praseodymium, rubidium, samarium, thulium, and ytterbium are not shown because available information regarding prices was inadequate. For those commodities with a single price source, please refer to that commodity chapter's Salient Statistics table.

overview.eaover: Each mineral commodity chapter of the 2025 edition of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Mineral Commodity Summaries (MCS) includes information on events, trends, and issues for each mineral commodity. Additionally, there is introductory material that provides an overview of events, trends, and issues of the mineral industry as a whole. The data used for the tables and figures of this introductory material have been converted to a csv format as part of the Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025 Data Release. Subjects include industry employment and earnings, total mine production, downstream manufacturing production indexes, capacity utilization. Economic data are also provided for industries that use nonfuel mineral commodities, such as housing, vehicle sales, and highway construction. There is a State table showing value and rank for the mineral industries on a geographic basis.Another table provides net import reliance for those mineral commodities for which the United States is the most dependent on a supply of imports. A special critical minerals table provides additional information on U.S and world production and apparent consumption.
overview.eadetcit: Companion data for graphs and figures of the introductory material in Mineral Commodity Summaries 2025

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
